question.text: Although much carbon dioxide is carried in the blood, yet blood does not become acidic because

options.text: <math><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></math> is continously diffused through the tissues and is not allowed to  accumulate

<math><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></math> combines with water to form <math><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></math>, which is neutralized by <math><msub><mrow><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></math>
In <math><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></math> transport, blood buffers play an important role

solution.text:
Blood does not become acidic due to buffering action. Bicarbonates act as buffering agents.

H2O+ CO2⇌ H2CO3⇌H++HCO3-
